This morning, just a few hours after Selma's dream, the villagers moved about as if lightning had formed on all paths, not only outside, but also inside the houses, lightning in the kitchens and living rooms.
They moved as if their own bodies were completely foreign to them, as if all their joints were inflamed and even the objects they handled were highly flammable.
They spent the whole day grumbling about their own lives and, as far as possible, those of others.

They kept looking back to check if someone was creeping up on them with murderous intent, someone who had lost their mind and therefore had nothing left to lose, and they quickly looked back to the front again because someone without a mind could also attack head-on.
They looked up to rule out falling roof tiles, branches, or heavy lampshades.
They feared all animals because they believed they could break out of them more quickly than out of humans.
They made a detour around the docile cows that might possibly calve today, avoiding the dogs as well, even the very old ones that could barely stand, but might still go for their throats today.
On days like these, anything was possible.
Even a mangy dachshund could bite through a person's throat, and that was far more outlandish than an okapi.
Except for Selma's sister-in-law Elsbeth, the people in the village were not superstitious.
They did nonchalantly all the things that one must not do when superstitious:.

They sat calmly under the clocks, even though superstition dictates that one can die from doing so, with their heads towards the door, even though superstition says that means they'll be carried out feet-first through that very door soon.
They hung out laundry between Christmas and New Year's, which, as Elsbeth warned, is considered a superstition akin to suicide or murder.
